intro: Lappula subdecumbens var. coerulescens, commonly known as blue lappula, is a flowering plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, cruciform flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils and is often found in open habitats such as meadows and riverbanks. Its leaves are lance-shaped and hairy, while the flowers are pale blue to violet in color. The species is noted for its ecological importance, providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a food source for certain herbivorous insects.
